body.p:
Your letter of 12 Nov, 11 Dec & 4 Jany are
before me I would have been[?] replied to before this but really I
have been & am still so occupied that I could not spare time
before, the affairs of our Congregation have been extremely
heavy for me as you shall find, I will firstly reply to your
letter of Dec. You are quite correct when you state that I
am interested for you. I have always been, & am so still, this
has been the reason of my always writing you in the stile I do.
I regret to find that you had been so indisposed. I hurt that
your health has since been perfectly re-established.

Mr Nans.[?] and myself are at variance, because at
his arrival I placed every confidence in him as an old friend
& a man being alike friendly to myself as well as to the party
appeared to me, & one to when I considered devoted the duty of
interfering & reconciling all the evils of the hart, but in
stead of that
he inserted[?] himself under the banner and did
all he could to annoy & vex him me, being then in appearance
friendly disposed, he concocted a letter which Dr Peixotto signed as President
Addressed to the head of the Commission for framing the new laws
in which he reviled me shamefully. I attacked him upon it
& he acknowledged it; for this & other reasons I withdrew from him
& not only myself but other highly respectable members of the
congregation lost the opinion they held of him, he then became
a leader of the party; & continued to do all he could to annoy,
this led him to be in[?] agreement M Nathan as well as to
myself, making use of no measured language, calling him a
Counting Priest &c.
I have written you so fully in the benefits

of confirmation that I will add what has really come
under my notice, there was 3 entire families here, who previously
to Mr Carillons [?], & were on the eve of apostatizing, his
instructions for the confirmation & private arguments completely
brought them back to their duty. I have since had the pleasure
of beholding its Moral & Religious effects upon the Young
people who now venerate their religion because they begin to
understand it. it is only a few whose opinions are lax
and are desirous of helping their children in ignorance of true
religion that are so violently opposed to it because they are
afraid that their children will reproach them for not keeping
the Sabbath & holy days which is strictly enforced in the
Catechism, the proof that it is well received is, that Mr
Nathan will confirm 14 young people in Passover. I am sorry
that we do not agree upon this point, for experience has confined
my opinion of its benefits & I am resolved to promote it with
all my might. Mr Nathan would have replied but the
man has been so annoyed by the conduct of Simmonds & his
party that I do not for the life of me know how he could
get thro' his duties as well as he did, added to it, we
have a heavy task to get through the new laws, the heaviest
part falling upon himself & myself;–I saw him last night,
he promises to reply very soon.–By the Bye I have never
secured the Occident for September. Please to forward it.

I now come to our Congregational Matters under the
Administration of Simmonds & his friends. I informed you of
the abuses of power in some cases, these continued so
long, & new ones were added that enacted[?] a great stir in the
Congregation & very many that had been opposed to me, now
saw that the reports they were against me were false; at
length Simmonds quitted the Island for the purpose of
marrying her Brother with a lady at Caracao , by which the

the administration of the Synagogue was only left in the
hands of 4 instead of 7 persons—5 of the body forming a
quorum, two of the members at the election refused to act &
never did as long as the Quorum was complete no one opposed
the legality.–but at Simmonds leaving, he with the 4 others
balloted [?] out of 2 instead of 4 Wardens as the law orders
to fill the place of President; now previous to balloting for
a new the old President must resign, as soon as he did
this, the body was reduced to 4 which were not a quorum &
had not the power of doing any business, consequently the
balloting was illegal; the most respectable members of
the Congregation represented the business to [?] & showed
the necessity of the Government of the Congregation being filled
up & of a new election for that purpose (the laws of the
Congregation does not provide for such a state of things,)
the Government who knew I were heartily disgusted with
all the proceedings of the entire party since the affair
with Carellion who saw how every thing had gone to [?]
[?], & who know that these people were improper ones to
be in the Government, appointed me President & Messrs
O[?] & Fidangree[?] Wardens, & then ordered an entire new
election of 7. this the 4 Remaining of Simmonds Administration
protested against, & as the were the majority I could not carry
out the Government order, I informed Government of it & sent in
the protest, the Governor immediately dismissed them from their
offices & placed Miss Rothschild, Dr DeCortz, Dr Monsato
& Isaac Pritt[?] in their stead the Board to continue until
further orders:–we found the affairs in a very bad &
neglected state, the circular they published was proved to be
incorrect in all its parts, the Synagogue was in need of repair
the [?] at the Burial Ground in a very bad state, and
[?] the minister & every other officer in credit. The Minister

for 6 months pay as well as the other officers, we required
$1200 over & above the Taxes to make the Synagogue clear,
in consequence we determined to call a meeting of the
congregation & lay before the members an expose (I could
get the sum required by [?] pay $250 per year) previous
to having any idea of calling a general meeting, I wrote
a letter to Nans proposing a reconciliation of all that had
passed & asking him to use his influence with those over
whom I know he had influence to forget & bury the past
remote[?] for the general good. I did this for the common
good, with no view to my particular standing, because I
was already at the head of the Congregation placed there by
government, & consequently not in need of the suffrages of
any one—the act was purely religious—his reply was of
a nature that in time will make him feel regret & a
refusal; except upon terms that could never have been
acceded to by any will in either of the congregation, he
wanted us to go back—only have Readers without pulpit
instruction, to do away with Taxes & substitute offerings
to them upon the religiously inclined the whole burthen of
maintaining the establishment, at length the meeting
took place at that meeting he and the arguments quoted
which was met by a vote of 3 to 1, against him, & his party
of 10 persons, he promises that affairs shall be worse than

ever, then you see his conduct, the Governor being very
much displeased with his & his party' doings did not invite
any one of them to a Ball he gave for some Dutch Naval
Officers, this has made him more furious, but thank God
he cannot injure altho he may annoy, you can form no
idea of the trouble I have had to re-arrange the affairs.
the Synagogue is under repair, the Burial House will be, the
people beg me to pay their taxes. Mr Nathan has consented
to leave his Salary & in a little time the Sunday School will
be again alone—in spite of the distractions

Pray send me the [?] Volume of the Pentateuch in
place of the one that was injured & returned we shall soon
require it. The new Laws will go into Government in the
Month. I have no time to recapitulate all the insults to
Mr Nathan, Mr Bay had a circumcision at his house, he
wrote to inform me & stated that he did not require the
services of the Minister, insulting him thus publicly. Bay is
Naan son in law

I regret to state that my son Moses has been
obliged to take his name off of the list of subscribers to the
Occident for the ensuing Year, business having gone bad with
him, 3d [?] Naan refused to pay his tax yesterday. I
will not enforce it by law as I am determined to do the
opposite of that which he & party desire. I will be moderate
& put up with their opposition as far as I can without
creating more bad feeling, it is awful to live among such
bad spirits;–you can suppose that neither himself for any of
his party of 10 came to the Synagogue, they cannot be accused
of having done often previously–
With best wishes I am My Dr Sir
